title: How to tell if my novel is written well - Quora

response.answer_text: Simply put: you can’t. Art is totally subjective.  There are two ways of judging your art: 1, whether it has commercial appeal, and 2, whether you’re satisfied with the final result.  1) Nobody can predict bestsellers. If someone could, that person would be a billionaire. Your agent or publisher has access to the same information as everyone else.  They can make judgments based on previous or projected data, but nobody really knows. That’s what getting work published is difficult: you have to convince an agent or publisher that your work is low-risk with a high profit potential. This isn’t easy to do, especially as a first-time or new author.  That’s where social media marketing and internet following comes into play, but I won’t bore you with those details. Long story short: the larger a premade audience you bring to the table, the better your chances are, because you’re providing some kind of risk mitigation. Devoted fanbase = better chance of people actually buying your books.  There’s a wealth of info about self-marketing your work, so check that out if you like.  2) Are you satisfied with what you’ve created? Is it what you imagined it? Is it something you’re proud of? Then you’ve already succeeded and you have nothing further to prove to anyone. You’re a success. Congratulations.  “Well written” is very subjective. If you asked 100 random people to read it, you’d probably end up with something like this:  25% loved it 25% hated it 50% thought it was “so-so”  So you can see that’s not much help.  Personally, I never concern myself with wondering “Is this a great book?”. I just do what feels right to me. I figure if I do that well and often enough, someone somewhere will like my vibe and voice and take a chance on me.  I think that’s about the only solace you’ll find as an artist. If you’re asking people “Is my novel any good?”, you’re pretty much wasting your time. Nobody can tell you. There’s no clear demarcation between “good” and “bad”, because it’s highly subjective. Sometimes total crap because a bestseller while great work never sees the light of day. Try not to stress about that sort of thing. Follow your heart, never try to imitate others (especially not your heroes or influences), and give the world your voice and your message. That’s about all any artist can do. Whether or not you get profits, applause, and awards is entirely out of your hands. That’s up to the fickle tastes of the general public, and predicting their vagaries is impossible…so don’t worry about it.  JKW. Just Keep Writing.  Rob

The short answer is, you can’t. Seriously, if you’ve spent hours writing things, you are always convinced it’s great. The fact that you have asked this question is a brilliant sign that you are aware of your own inadequacies as an editor of your own works. That is good, believe me! The first thing you can do is read the whole thing aloud. Not in public, just to yourself. When you read aloud, all sorts of little glitches and grammatical errors will occur to you. All professional writers do this. It is important to print your work too. Don’t think you can edit on a screen. On a computer, your eyes will skim read more than when you have the pages in front of you. Read aloud c arefully, and listen for where you stumble and hesitate. Those are the bits you need to work on. After that, I can recommend finding friends who are willing to read it for you. Perhaps not the whole book, but even if they read two or three chapters, they can give you an honest opinion. BUT Make sure you know what they like to read. If their highest literary aspiration is 50 Shades of Grey, and you have written a great crime novel … well, they may not be the subjective audience you need!

That’s tougher than it sounds. And it’s a sliding scale unless you know where the bar needs to be set. If you are good, you still might not be as good as Dickens or Twain. But since a lot of people who write well aren’t as good as those people you shouldn’t make that your standard. It also means that you are not just determining if the story is good but that the writing and structure are good. The problem is, amateurs are very good at telling you what you got wrong without you knowing whether they are correct or not. Some writing advice is genuine crap. I had a round of Alpha readers on my first novel just kind of hedge on getting back to me, and several of them didn’t finish the novel. I took that as somewhat of a hint all by itself. (I now have a new set of friends, as the old joke goes.) But their advice was all over the place in terms of usability. They would often miss elements that I thought a sophisticated reader should pick up on, and I thought if I dumbed those down too much it would be condescending. On other parts they had the issues dead to rights. It also should be made clear to you that getting someone to alpha/beta read for you is a huge favor on their part. People are busy and how eager would you be if you had a full schedule and one of your friends asked you to take a gander at their writing? Alpha readers are pretty helpful but sadly they are not all created equal. And they’ll each have their own theory as to what parts you got wrong. Some of them will have heard advice like “never end a sentence with a preposition” and take you to task on that as if it were going to kill your chance of being published. (If you still think that, I recommend the article by Grammar Girl Ending a Sentence With a Preposition ) My point being, they can tell you something like that and become impossible to get further along with the critique. So, to write well you have to succeed at different levels. You have have spelling and grammar right at the lowest level, and you can use software to find that. I point people to grammarly for the basic stuff and Hemingway Editor for slightly more complex stuff. Try it out on the free level before you get too excited. But these can spot some of the garbage elements in your work. At the highest level you need a plot that works and has a satisfying end. If you’ve got that then you’ve got a lot. If you don’t have that, then you need to fix it. For the mid-level, I like to read the thing aloud. I use another piece of software that can do that called yWriter, but there are others (I use yWriter to write the novels in so the speak-and-spell tool is right at hand). Hearing a voice speak your words is good for picking up on twisted and gnarled sections that you need to smooth out. It gives me a sense of flow, and a sense of pacing. For my part, I like to work scene by scene for some things and re-read and rewrite a lot. Once you have it to the point where you think a person would buy it off the rack if it were published, that’s really when you take it to the Beta readers. Which may have to be different people than your Alpha readers just because they won’t have seen the work before. After you’ve fixed all the things you agree with from the Betas, then you can approach an editor (IMO, of course, as all of this is). The point being that an editor is going to throw stuff out that is substandard in many of the categories you’ll have worked on. I recommend that you examine the books “The First Five Pages” and “The First Fifty Pages”. If you find, as most of us do, that you have weak sections of your ability to write, then identify them, work on them, and don’t worry too much about them. For some, it’s dialog, for others, it’s description. Or too much expository writing. Or clumsy expository dialog. tl;dr…. You can tell if you didn’t write it well if you get a lot of your test readers yawning, confused, or angry that you wasted their time.

These are some questions I was asked to answer after the fact, for publicity. Choose an excerpt that you would want to be used.List your primary characters and show why they are important to the storyA brief summaryWhat do you want your readers to take away from reading your novelWhat are the main themes of your novelHow is your novel different than othersThen read your novel out loud and listen to the rhythm of the language, the use of figures of speech. Notice if it makes you laugh, feel moved to different emotions. Notice if it makes you pause to relish the descriptions. Notice if there are any foreshadowings you can recognize. Notice if it has moments that make you pause in your breathing. Notice if you can find yourself in it. It at points you pause and think, ‘this is good, did I really write this?’ If you can do these things, you can be pretty certain that you’ve just read a well written novel
Find someone like a literature teacher who is willing to read and critique it.

Ask someone familiar with the genre to read with a critical eye. Join a critique group. There are several online that offer free tit-for-tat exchanges. I use Critique Circle. If you’re already beyond the crit phase and have readers, ask your betas for honest feedback. Avoid the folks who will try to please you. Follow up with your crit partners/ beta readers and ask for specifics. Goals, motivation, conflict (internal/ external): are they clear for the main characters?Where did they slow down?Ask them to flag where they paused to take a break. Did others do the same? Ask yourself why.Add end notes in the manuscript at the end of key chapters or pivot points. Request specific feedback: are you hooked? worried? how’s my pace? Do you want to turn the page?Good luck and have fun! It’s a roller coaster of a journey!

Get somebody who reads a lot of books to read it. And by “a lot,” I mean, a lot. Don’t ask someone who has only read Harry Potter and claims to be a “huge book nerd”. Preferably, ask an author, although many of them can’t read unpublished work for legal reasons, so ask somebody who is a librarian, bookstore owner, etc. who has clear likes and dislikes. Join a writers’ circle where you can receive constructive criticism. You can only really tell if you get a second opinion, to be completely honest.

Get people who are not your personal friends or family to read it, or at least excerpts. You are more likely to get an honest opinion. Ideally, pay a professional editor to read it and you’ll get an opinion that is not only honest but knowledgeable. Join a writing group and offer your own feedback to others in return.

Your editor will tell you. If you're self-publishing, the number of sales will tell you, though it's a bit harder to gauge when you self-publish, as sales are mainly a function of advertising efforts (rather than quality).

Pay someone you trust to read it. Why pay? Because then they will know you want to hear more than I liked it or I didn't like it. Before they read it, tell them that you want to know what they liked and, more importantly, what they didn't like. You need not pay a lot but you are asking for several hours of their time.
Give it to someone you trust and likes books a lot. They will give you much feedback on it and you will know what to do.
